thread.title: Gallant Crows can hold heads high, but Eagles simply too good at home | The
thread.title_full: Gallant Crows can hold heads high, but Eagles simply too good at home | The Advertiser

author: RICHARD EARLE Perth
title: Gallant Crows can hold heads high, but Eagles simply too good at home | The
text:
SOMETHING had to give.
They came and honoured late coach Phil Walsh but there’s no room for sentiment on the field as West Coast duly illustrated with a 56-point win against Adelaide at Subiaco.
The Eagles had swooped for five wins as many games against interstate sides at Subiaco this year with an average margin of 71 points and professionally added Adelaide to the list.
This was more than a game for clubs both served by Walsh.
Taylor Walker’s men were clapped on to the field by classy Eagles fans while interim director of football John Worsfold enjoyed a standing ovation at his old stamping ground. The game ended as it started, in silence with players arm-in-arm.
The Crows can hold their heads high just for getting in the head space for a contest and still having a sniff starting the final term 29 points down.
Slick runner Riley Knight (two) will always cherish his first goal on debut in a third term rally. Scott Camporeale held firm on debut as head coach in an unprecedented night of football heartache, occupying Walsh’s old seat.
Gallant Adelaide had spent a lifetime of emotion, leading by 14 points at quarter time in a contest West Coast would run away with.
The Eagles were supercharged by ruckman Nic Naitanui and midfielders Andrew Gaff (three and 36 touches) and Chris Masten (35). Luke Shuey celebrated 100 games with two goals.
Crows press conference with interim coach Scott Camporeale 7:33 Play video
AFL: Adelaide Crows interim coach Scott Camporeale talks to the media following his side's loss to the West Coast Eagles.
Fox Sports 11 Jul 2015 Sport/AFL/News Mark Le Cras, Elliott Yeo, Jack Darling, Gaff, Josh Kennedy, Scott Selwood, Sharrod Wellingham and Josh Hill combined to boot eight unanswered goals in a devastating, Eagles second-term riposte.
Adelaide floundered with brilliant but hurt Patrick Dangerfield off the field until the 13th minute of the second term but nothing was going to hold back a West Coast tsunami.
Tom Lynch was eventually used a defensive spare but the damage was done.
Dangerfield had a tooth knocked out and mouth badly split. The clutch onballer’s absence emphasised the importance of a 13-possession first term complete with eight contested possessions.
A 54-point turnaround iced the contest before the main break — with Adelaide paying dearly for 33 turnovers.
Walsh brought the forward press to West Coast with dramatic effect in its 2011 surge to a preliminary final. Now Adam Simpson’s ensemble have taken it to another level, stunning the competition with a rise to second despite injuries to key defenders Mitch Brown and Eric Mackenzie.
The Eagles are exceptional at locking the ball in their forward half, forcing turnovers and stoppages and scoring off the back as Gaff and Yeo proved.
Adelaide still deserved credit for a resolute first term after West Coast jumped to a three-goal start.
Five of Adelaide’s first six goals would come from discerning chips over the defence as the Crows became the first interstate side to briefly threaten West Coast press strategy
Charlie Cameron — triggered Adelaide surge. Picture: Mark Brake Source: News Corp Australia
Charlie Cameron (two) triggered Adelaide’s exploitation of the West Coast press as the Crows slotted five straight goals. Cameron had a hand in Adelaide’s third, offloading to Josh Jenkins who the selflessly allowed Taylor Walker to enjoy an open goal.
This was Phil Walsh’s team-first footy.
Ultimately, West Coast’s sheer line-by-line superiority would prevail.
The Eagles have crushed opposition in all key hallmarks this season and did last night winning clearances (22-13) inside 50s 73-37.
However Adelaide led the Eagles for tackles (57-51) and led Walsh’s pet ground ball get category 54-48.
Daniel Talia can be consoled with a blanket job on Josh Kennedy while Matt Crouch showed glimpses of star quality.
WEST COAST 4.0 12.7 15.10 22.15 (147)
ADELAIDE 6.2 6.3 11.5 4.7 (91)
GOALS — West Coast: Gaff (3) Yeo (3), Le Cras (2) Darling (2), Shuey (2), Hill (2) Kennedy (2) Priddis, Wellingham, Selwood, Sheed, Masten, Naitanui
Adelaide: Walker (3), Cameron (2), Betts (2) Knight (2) Jenkins (2) Wright, Lynch, Smith
BEST — West Coast: Naitanui, Gaff, Le Cras, Masten, Rosa, Priddis. Adelaide: Dangerfield, Cameron, Crouch, Jenkins, Laird, Walker, Talia, Betts, Lever
UMPIRES — Dean Margetts, Jeff Dalgleish, David Harris
CROWD — 38,133 at Subiaco
